Key Arguments: The submission expresses discomfort and alarm at the assumptions behind the Bill.
The author believes that politicians should not determine 'the truth' for citizens.
There is concern about lawmakers deciding when views are 'harmful' and 'hateful', with definitions around 'hate' being seen as nebulous.
The author argues for the right to express views that may not align with prevailing ideologies or political messaging.
The submission suggests that instead of the Bill, there should be a focus on strengthening education to teach logical thinking and understanding multiple perspectives.
Main Themes: Skepticism towards government control over truth
Concerns about definitions of hate and harm
Education as a solution to misinformation
Notable Quotes: I didn’t vote for politicians to determine 'the truth' for me.
I shouldn’t have to agree with prevailing ideologies and political messaging in order to be considered a good citizen.
Please consider this and understand the fear of ordinary citizens who just want to have the right to make up their own minds and scrap this bill.
